_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Nursery, Garden Center, and Farm Supply Stores

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The management and employees of Western Farm Service, 16275 9th Street, Huron, California are committed to the prevention of a release of Anhydrous Ammonia, bulk Paraquat Chloride and pesticides.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility will work with the local fire department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  An emergency response plan has been developed and would be implemented in the event of a release.

2. The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The primary business at the facility is to sell fertilizers, agricultural pesticides and agro-nomic services to growers and ranchers.  To conduct this business, the following activities occur at the facility:

A. Storage and delivery of bulk and packaged containers of fertilizers, bulk and pack-aged containers of agricultural chemicals and packaged seed.  All fertilizer, agricul-tural chemicals and seed are distributed to growers.  No mixing or formulating of agricultural chemicals occurs at the facility.

B. 11 agricultural pesticides stored in the Chemical Warehouse are regulated substances accordng to the state of California.  The maximum process quantities (in pounds of active ingredient) of the regulated substances stored in the Chemical Warehouse are: Aldicarb (5832 pounds); Azinphos-Methyl (1188 pounds); Carbofuran (792 pounds); Dimethoate (5472 pounds); Endosulfan (1474 pounds); Fenamiphos (420 pounds); Methamidophos (200 pounds); Oxamyl (1512 pounds); Paraquat (3080 pounds); Phorate (216 pounds) and Phosmet (1512 pounds).

C. Anhydrous Ammonia is received and stored at the facility.  It is distributed to grow-ers for use as a plant nutrient.  Anhydrous Ammonia is received by truck and stored in a 30,000-gallon capacity aboveground storage tank.  The maximum quantity of Anhydrous Ammonia handled at the facility is

131,325 pounds.

D. Bulk Paraquat Dichloride is delivered and stored at the facility.  It is distributed to growers for use as a herbicide.  Paraquat Dichloride is stored in one aboveground storage tank.  The tank capacity is 2500 gallons.  The maximum quantity of Bulk Paraquat Dichloride handled at the facility is 11,000 pounds.

3. Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

CPS - Huron has calculated Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios for the regulated chemicals at the facility.  They are not included in the Executive Summary but are reported in the mani RMP text.

4. Accidental Release Prevention Program 

WFS Huron has comprehensive written programs and procedures to comply with the CalARP RMP program regulations.  Key to getting all programs and procedures in place was (1) having the facility management understand what the CalARP RMP regulations required and (2) developing and implementing specific written programs, written procedures and practices to meet those regulations.

Facility management and employees involved in any of the covered processes have been trained and made aware of the provisions and requirements in the programs and practices.

5.  Five-Year Accident History 

In the past five years, there have been no releases of Anhydrous Ammonia, Bulk Para-quat Dichloride or any of the 11 regulated substances stored in the Chemical Ware-house that have caused any deaths, injuries or property damage at the facility nor re-sulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, property damage or environmental dam-age.

6. The Emergency Response Program

The facility has an emergency response plan.  The local fire department has conducted a facility visit specifically addressing the response to releases of Anhydrous Ammonia, Bulk Paraquat Dichloride and products stored in the Chemical Warehouse.  One employee at the facility is trained as an emergency responder to the 24-Hour HAZWOPER Technician Level.  The facility emergency responder and the other e

mployees participate in an emergency response drill once each year.

7. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety is an on-going process at WFS Huron.  Inspections and audits are conducted periodically to determine how well the facility is in compliance with regulatory and company requirements.  At the time of this update, there were 18 risk reduction measures being considered by facility management for implementation.
